questions.text: The primary antagonist of the anterior tibial tendon is innervated by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The primary antagonist of the anterior tibial tendon is the peroneus longus, which is innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve.

  • The anterior tibial tendon (tendon of tibialis anterior) dorsiflexes and inverts the foot.
  • Its antagonist performs plantarflexion and eversion, which is primarily done by the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis muscles.
  • Both peroneus longus and brevis are innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve (branch of common peroneal nerve).
  • Thus, the superficial peroneal nerve supplies the muscles that oppose the action of tibialis anterior.

Explanation of other options:

Deep peroneal nerve (Option B): Innervates tibialis anterior and other anterior compartment muscles; not the antagonist, but rather the agonist.

Tibial nerve (Option C): Innervates posterior compartment muscles like tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus; contributes to plantarflexion but not eversion, so not the primary antagonist.

Posterior tibial nerve (Option D): There's no separate "posterior tibial nerve"; the term likely confuses tibial nerve itself or the posterior tibial artery.

questions.text: As part of a physical examination to evaluate lower limb function, a physician places her hands on the dorsum of the patient's foot and asks the patient to dorsiflex the ankle joint against resistance, as shown. What nerve is the doctor testing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dorsiflexion of the ankle is performed by muscles innervated by the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve, which is being tested here.

  • The deep fibular nerve (a branch of the common fibular nerve) innervates the anterior compartment of the leg, which includes muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the ankle such as the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, and extensor digitorum longus.
  • These muscles help lift the foot upwards, a movement critical for gait and balance.
  • During a physical exam, resisted dorsiflexion tests both muscle strength and the integrity of the deep fibular nerve.
  • If the patient cannot perform dorsiflexion or shows weakness, this could suggest injury or compression of the deep fibular nerve (e.g., at the fibular neck).

Explanation of other options:

Tibial nerve (Option A): Innervates the posterior compartment muscles, which are responsible for plantarflexion, not dorsiflexion.

Superficial fibular nerve (Option C): Supplies the lateral compartment of the leg (e.g., fibularis longus and brevis) responsible for eversion, not dorsiflexion.

Medial plantar nerve (Option D): Branch of the tibial nerve that innervates intrinsic foot muscles and skin on the plantar side, unrelated to dorsiflexion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old mixed martial arts fighter could not continue his fight after receiving a side leg kick to the neck of his left fibula. The fighter reported paresthesia and numbness on the entire dorsum of his left foot. During his physical examination, the patient often stumbled with his left toes dragging on the floor during the swing phase of his gait. Asymmetry in his normal foot position was also noted by the physician (see photo) as well as weakness in eversion of the foot at the ankle joint. What nerve was damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An injury at the fibular neck affects the common fibular nerve, causing loss of dorsiflexion, eversion, and sensation over the dorsum of the foot.

  • The common fibular (peroneal) nerve winds around the neck of the fibula, making it superficial and vulnerable to trauma, such as a direct kick.
  • It divides into two terminal branches:
    • Deep fibular nerve: supplies the anterior compartment of the leg and responsible for dorsiflexion.
    • Superficial fibular nerve: supplies the lateral compartment and responsible for eversion, and provides sensation to most of the dorsum of the foot.
  • Damage to the common fibular nerve results in:
    • Foot drop (due to loss of dorsiflexion),
    • Weakened eversion, and
    • Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot.
  • The patient's foot dragging, paresthesia, and weakness in eversion all point to damage proximal to the bifurcation-i.e., the common fibular nerve.

Explanation of other options:

Tibial nerve (Option A): Supplies posterior compartment for plantarflexion and intrinsic foot muscles, not involved in dorsiflexion or eversion.

Deep fibular nerve (Option B): Controls dorsiflexion and toe extension, but eversion and most dorsal foot sensation would be spared if only this branch were injured.

Superficial fibular nerve (Option C): Controls eversion and sensation to dorsum, but dorsiflexion would be preserved, this option does not explain foot drop.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is a branch of the sacral plexus?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • The marked structure "B" is a branch of the sacral plexus, which gives rise to the sciatic nerve, the largest nerve in the body.
  • The sacral plexus is formed by the lumbosacral trunk (L4-L5) and ventral ramus of S1 to S4.
  • It lies on the posterior pelvic wall, anterior to the piriformis muscle.
  • The most important nerve arising from this plexus is the sciatic nerve (L4-S3).
  • The sciatic nerve exits the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis and enters the gluteal region.
  • It typically splits into:
    • Tibial nerve (posterior compartment of the leg and plantar foot), and
    • Common fibular nerve (anterior and lateral compartments of the leg and dorsum of foot).
  • These nerves control motor and sensory innervation of most of the lower limb, excluding the anterior thigh and medial leg.

questions.text: Furcal nerve is an independent spinal nerve which arises commonly from the
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The furcal nerve most commonly arises from the L4 spinal nerve, and it connects the lumbar and sacral plexuses.

  • The furcal nerve (also called the prefixed communicating nerve) is an independent nerve that most commonly originates from L4, though it may occasionally come from L3 or L5.
  • It acts as a link between the lumbar and sacral plexuses, contributing fibers to both the femoral nerve (lumbar plexus) and the lumbosacral trunk (which becomes part of the sacral plexus).
  • Thus, it plays a significant role in mixed innervation patterns and overlapping dermatomes, especially in cases involving lumbosacral radiculopathies.

questions.text: A car strikes a pedestrian on the lateral side of her leg. Following the accident, she had a fracture. Her foot hangs loosely in plantar flexion when she raises it off the ground. She can still invert her foot, but cannot evert it. She can flex but not extend her toes. Which nerve is most likely to have been damaged in the fracture given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The fracture shown is at the neck of the fibula. Common fibular nerve is most commonly injured in fractures of the neck of the fibula, as it winds superficially around it.
  • The common fibular (peroneal) nerve is a terminal branch of the sciatic nerve.
  • After bifurcating from the sciatic nerve in the popliteal fossa, it winds laterally around the neck of the fibula, where it lies superficially beneath the skin and is vulnerable to trauma, such as in fibular neck fractures.
  • Injury here can result in:
    • Foot drop due to paralysis of anterior and lateral compartment muscles (deep and superficial fibular nerves).
    • Sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and lateral shin.

Explanation of other options:

Tibial nerve (Option B): Runs deep in the posterior compartment and is not close to the fibular neck and less likely to be injured in this fracture.

Obturator nerve (Option C): Innervates medial thigh muscles and passes through the pelvis and is not related to the fibular region.

Saphenous nerve (Option D): A sensory branch of the femoral nerve that runs medially in the leg and not anatomically near the fibular neck.

questions.text: In which of the following nerve injury eversion flick, high stepping gait is seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Common peroneal nerve injury leads to foot drop, causing a high-stepping gait with an eversion flick during walking.

  • Footdrop is another characteristic gait, which is caused by damage to the common or deep fibular nerve.
  • The common fibular nerve wraps around the head of fibula, so blunt trauma or fracture here can lead to foot drop.
  • The deep fibular nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg. These muscles dorsiflex the foot, which is required during the swing phase to clear the toes away from the ground.
  • If the deep fibular nerve is damaged, then the foot cannot be dorsiflexed, and drags along the ground during the swing phase.
  • To compensate for the lack of dorsiflexion during the swing phase, the patient may reverse the foot in a sudden motion, called an 'eversion flick'.
  • Another common compensatory movement is hyperflexion of the thigh at the hip to help the dropped foot clear the floor, known as "high steppage gait".

Explanation of other options:

Tibial nerve (Option A): Injury causes loss of plantarflexion and inversion, not dorsiflexion; no high-stepping gait.

Obturator nerve (Option C): Affects adduction of the thigh; no role in foot dorsiflexion or eversion.

Saphenous nerve (Option D): A purely sensory branch of the femoral nerve-does not supply any foot or leg muscles.

questions.text: The muscle marked as 'B' is supplied by?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The muscles marked as B is the short head of biceps femoris. The short head of biceps femoris is the only hamstring-related muscle supplied by the common fibular division of the sciatic nerve.

The biceps femoris has two heads:

  • Long head: arises from ischial tuberosity, is a true hamstring muscle, and is innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve.
  • Short head: arises from the linea aspera of the femur (not ischial tuberosity) and is innervated by the common fibular (peroneal) division of the sciatic nerve.
  • This division is a notable exception to the general rule that hamstring muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve.

Explanation of other options:

Tibial nerve (Option B): Supplies the long head of biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus, but not the short head.

Femoral nerve (Option C): Supplies the anterior compartment of thigh (e.g., quadriceps), not the biceps femoris.

Obturator nerve (Option D): Innervates medial thigh muscles (e.g., adductors), has no supply to the posterior thigh.

questions.text: Which compartment of the leg does not have neurovascular bundles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral compartment of the leg lacks its own dedicated neurovascular bundle.

  • The lateral compartment (which houses the fibularis longus and brevis muscles) does not contain a neurovascular bundle of its own within the compartment.
  • It receives:
    • Motor supply from the superficial fibular nerve (which travels outside the compartment before entering).
    • Blood supply indirectly via perforating branches of the fibular artery and anterior tibial artery.
  • Hence, the lateral compartment of the leg doesn't have a neurovascular bundle.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior compartment (Option A): Contains the deep fibular nerve and anterior tibial artery/vein, a clear neurovascular bundle.

Posterior compartment (Option B): Contains tibial nerve, posterior tibial artery, and fibular artery, well-developed neurovascular structures.

Medial compartment (Option D): This option is a distractor. The leg has no medial compartment anatomically, this option is invalid.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with bone cancer in the fibula that necessitates its removal. Which of the following muscles would be least affected following removal of the fibula?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Flexor digitorum longus originates from the posterior surface of the tibia, not the fibula, so it remains unaffected by fibular removal.

  • The fibula serves as the site of origin or insertion for several muscles in the lateral, anterior, and posterior compartments of the leg.
  • However, flexor digitorum longus (FDL) arises from the medial part of the posterior tibia, not from the fibula.
  • Therefore, even if the fibula is removed (e.g., during resection for tumor), FDL function is preserved.
  • Other muscles like:
    • Extensor digitorum longus: arises partly from fibula. (Option B ruled out)
    • Biceps femoris (short head): originates from fibula. (Option A ruled out)
    • Flexor hallucis longus: originates from the inferior 2/3 of posterior fibula. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A pedestrian is struck by a car, and his fibular neck is fractured. There is no indication of foot drop, but he cannot evert his foot and the top of his foot is numb. This apparent nerve lesion would affect which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Eversion of the foot and sensation over the dorsum are both mediated by the superficial fibular nerve, which innervates fibularis longus and brevis. B and E correspond to Fibularis brevis and Fibularis longus respectively.


  • The common fibular (peroneal) nerve divides into:
    • Deep fibular nerve → supplies anterior compartment (e.g., tibialis anterior → dorsiflexion).
    • Superficial fibular nerve → supplies lateral compartment muscles:
      • Fibularis longus
      • Fibularis brevis
  • A fracture at the neck of the fibula often affects the common fibular nerve, but in this case:
    • No foot drop → deep fibular nerve (which innervates dorsiflexors) is spared
    • Loss of eversion → superficial fibular nerve is affected (lateral compartment)
    • Numbness on dorsum of foot → sensory branch of superficial fibular nerve involved
  • Thus, fibularis longus and brevis are the affected muscles.

questions.text: A long distance runner complained of swelling and pain in his shin. At physical examination, skin testing showed normal cutaneous sensation of the leg. However, muscular strength tests showed marked weakness of dorsiflexion and impaired inversion of the foot. Which nerve serves the muscles involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot are controlled by anterior compartment muscles, innervated by the deep fibular nerve which is marked as D in the given image.

  • The anterior compartment of the leg contains the following key muscles:
    • Tibialis anterior - dorsiflexion + inversion
    • Extensor hallucis longus - dorsiflexion of great toe
    • Extensor digitorum longus - dorsiflexion of lateral four toes
    • Fibularis tertius - weak dorsiflexion + eversion
  • These muscles are innervated by the deep fibular nerve, a terminal branch of the common fibular nerve.
  • In this case:
    • Marked weakness of dorsiflexion → tibialis anterior & other dorsiflexors affected
    • Impaired inversion → tibialis anterior affected (primary inverter, along with tibialis posterior)
    • Normal cutaneous sensation → deep fibular nerve has minimal skin territory (only first web space); rest of leg skin sensation is from superficial fibular and saphenous nerves, which are unaffected

Crural fascia

  • Crural fascia is the deep fascia of the leg (i.e., the fascia covering the region between the knee and ankle).
  • Key Features:
    • Continuation of fascia lata (deep fascia of the thigh) below the knee.
    • Tough, dense connective tissue that invests the leg like a sleeve.
    • Attaches to the anterior and medial borders of the tibia and fibula.
  • Functions:
    • Compartmentalization:
      • The crural fascia gives rise to intermuscular septa; Anterior intermuscular septum, Posterior intermuscular septum, Transverse intermuscular septum
      • These septa divide the leg into three main compartments:
        • Anterior (dorsiflexors)
        • Lateral (evertors)
        • Posterior (plantar flexors) → further subdivided into superficial and deep compartments.
    • Muscle Efficiency:
      • Helps direct the pull of muscles during contraction.
      • Prevents bulging of muscles during activity → improves venous return.
    • Clinical Relevance - Compartment Syndrome:
      • Because the crural fascia is non-distensible, trauma or bleeding within a compartment can lead to increased intracompartmental pressure → compressing nerves and vessels → compartment syndrome, a surgical emergency.
